Article.ArticleTitle: Species-specific variation of photosynthesis and mesophyll conductance to ozone and drought in three Mediterranean oaks.

AbstractText: Mesophyll conductance (g<sub>mCO2</sub> ) is one of the most important components in plant photosynthesis. Tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) and drought impair physiological processes, causing damage to photosynthetic systems. However, the combined effects of O<sub>3</sub> and drought on g<sub>mCO2</sub> are still largely unclear. We investigated leaf gas exchange during mid-summer in three Mediterranean oaks exposed to O<sub>3</sub> (ambient [35.2 nmol mol<sup>-1</sup> as daily mean]; 1.4 × ambient) and water treatments (WW [well-watered] and WD [water-deficit]). We also examined if leaf traits (leaf mass per area [LMA], foliar abscisic acid concentration [ABA]) could influence the diffusion of CO<sub>2</sub> inside a leaf. The combination of O<sub>3</sub> and WD significantly decreased net photosynthetic rate (P<sub>N</sub> ) regardless of the species. The reduction of photosynthesis was associated with a decrease in g<sub>mCO2</sub> and stomatal conductance (g<sub>sCO2</sub> ) in evergreen Quercus ilex, while the two deciduous oaks (Q. pubescens, Q. robur) also showed a reduction of the maximum rate of carboxylation (V<sub>cmax</sub> ) and maximum electron transport rate (J<sub>max</sub> ) with decreased diffusive conductance parameters. The reduction of g<sub>mCO2</sub> was correlated with increased [ABA] in the three oaks, whereas there was a negative correlation between g<sub>mCO2</sub> with LMA in Q. pubescens. Interestingly, two deciduous oaks showed a weak or no significant correlation between g<sub>sCO2</sub> and ABA under high O<sub>3</sub> and WD due to impaired stomatal physiological behaviour, indicating that the reduction of P<sub>N</sub> was related to g<sub>mCO2</sub> rather than g<sub>sCO2</sub> . The results suggest that g<sub>mCO2</sub> plays an important role in plant carbon gain under concurrent increases in the severity of drought and O<sub>3</sub> pollution.
